97225579.review:
Absolutely brilliant game that captures all the things you want about exploring an alien world, and then exploiting it mercilessly, after you work out how to not let it kill you.  Base building, crafting, resource management are superb.  9/10 because of some lagging, but it is early access, so excellent effort. 

Serious talk though, and an actual warning:  If you are a hypomaniac like me, you need to approach this game carefully.  I have played 201 hours in the last 14 days, and only just broke free from it.  I am not actually joking here.  I think it is a dangerous game for obsessives and completionists.  I'm sure the devs didn't mean to create a Time Sink to rule them all, but here we are...

97179024.review:
I mentally compare this game to the first save I had in Minecraft after discovering how redstone works.
I made a creative mode save, set it to superflat, and spent hundreds of hours trying out builds for TNT cannons, auto-farms, and other crazy contraptions.

Coffee Stain devs looked at this way of playing Minecraft and decided to make a game just like it, and this we have Satisfactory.

Satisfactory is just about the perfect definition of an open-ended base building game. Its designed to equip players with the power to build easily, yet without limiting them to simple structures. You start just by collecting material and building some things to get you off the ground, then you unlock some simple automations, then more complex automations, and then, before you even realized, you've gone from having to hand-collect iron to having 18 auto-miners with 3-5 smelters each, a constructor to each smelter, and a maze of conveyor belts so complex that it reminds you of an old Windows XP screensaver.

This game is the perfect way to unwind and kill any amount of time. It sparks enough creativity to be captivating yet only requires as much deep attention as you want it to.

97148217.review:
Definitely a game to play for those who liked Factorio or games which focus on optimisation and efficiency. The game mechanics are complex and unique yet are reasonably easy to understand for players who are new to the genre. Plenty of guides online which help with understanding game knowledge. Highly recommend a youtuber named "Scalti" as he has a lot of videos on early game builds and general knowledge on game mechanics which are easy to understand. Although the game is restricted to a set map, it has various areas which will benefit different players at different levels. 

In terms of difficulty, it's pretty chill as the game doesn't force you to progress with any questlines or storylines, which there aren't, so you can take it at your own pace. 

Has high replayability potential as the your first run would most likely be discovering the game and its map, whereas your future runs will be fully optimising your builds. There's also large community that provide mods which I highly recommend trying out as well, maybe on your 3rd or 4th run as it'll make it just 100 times better. 

Be cautious though, as gameplay might be a bit physically nauseating for some people because of the player and camera movement. If you get nauseous playing Portal or Minecraft, maybe look at some gameplay and see how you feel. 

10/10 definitely recommend for players who are interested in getting into factory building games.

97108475.review:
Pros -- beautifully built world, fun to explore, and MASSIVE. Immersive. Progression is rewarding and challenging.

Pro or Con depending on game preferences -- the world is essentially only hostile while exploring. My brother wishes this was like factorio where enemies would raid the base; I enjoy being able to let the factory sprawl without worrying about defenses. 

Cons -- buggy is the main issue. Fixed world, not procedural, which is ok, though I hope in the future they will have more than one map (though like I said above...it's HUGE). Also, there are little puzzles and well guarded treasures littered around the world, and about half of them yield a really nice "WIP" (work in progress) reward.....love going through the trouble of exploring or clearing enemies and wasting gas mask filters to pick up a nice piece of trash that even the factory's AWESOME SINK (incinerator) will reject.

Despite the cons, I absolutely love playing this. Spent over 100 hours, and still haven't finished the final tech tier in a factory. Looking forward to more good things to come with this game

97073490.review:
First note: this game is in Early Access still, and the developer is using that system properly.  Which means the game is deliberately incomplete and has bugs, though none game breaking that I have encountered.

Second note: the game currently has only an open, progressing build style to it.  There is no story mode, yet, so the only reason to do stuff is because you like doing stuff.

So, having gotten that out of the way, I enjoy playing it (albeit in smaller doses than many of its other fans), and recommend it to anyone who likes boots on the ground style construction sims.  However, since the focus is on building components, not building construction, the actual construction is handled by hand-wavium, and then the buildings make new parts for you.  Basically you chuck stuff out of your inventory and it turns into a new building.
The main point of the game, at least so, is to build intricate, efficient manufacturing systems that support further expanding said capacities.  Or creating a massive spaghetti monster of conveyor belts pipelines, and transit tubes, with the occasional out of place constructor you always forget about whenever you need more whatsits.  Either way works.

97046718.review:
This game gets EXTREMELY tedious towards end-game. I guess all the positive reviews are from people who haven't got further than coal tech? Because I can't imagine how anyone could feel that spending an entire evening building 50 or so buildings, and belting all of them, and powering all of them, and laying out foundation for them, AND DOING ALL OF THIS BY HAND EVERY TIME might be fun. I mean, yeah, it's fun do it once. Well, maybe twice. But you'll have to do it many, oh lord, so many times.

This game has NONE of the quality of life features that make this type of games enjoyable. No blueprints, no copy/paste or "stretching", no area actions, inventory is limited as fuck, only one active equipment item, you get bird-view WAY too late into the game, no mk2/mk3 production buildings, the list goes on and on, it's ridiculous. And from what I've read on forums, all of this is intentional? Like, THIS is their vision?

It's like devs forgot that planning and designing complex chains, and then seeing them come to life IS what makes these games fun. Certainly not clicking another 300 fucking times in a row to lay another 300 foundation tiles.

you know it's been a long time since i've really enjoyed a video game. i am rather depressed and i must say i don't do much anymore. but i can sink hours into satisfactory. what started as a small iron facility in the sparse and barren desert grew and grew and now houses steel and computer and iron and oil manufacturing spanning across beaches and deserts and grasslands and swamps and i can safely say after over 100 hours that i love this game.

97015050.review:
Good But:

Much of what is good about Space Engineers, Much of what is good about the inevitable comparison to Factorio, but much more fiddly than both. 

The programming achievement of this is nothing short of stunning given the amount of work it is doing to render what it is doing _but_ the lack of a blue printing system, the small scale, the fiddly nature of early stage spaghetti are much much harder to recover from than the inevitable comparisons because even a 2 story building represents a considerable number of clicks, and a good number more to clear for the next big thing. 

Waiting and tedious repetition of fine detail are what this game has against it. Gorgeous visuals, a satisfying loop, _objectives_ and tangible progress in everything you do for it. 

Beware oh you who are weak to low level dopamine loops, this will keep you up late.

96911444.review:
Like Factorio but 3d -- that is, a logistics based game where the point is to mine resources and automate processes to form those resources into productive assets, but in three dimensions.  The game is still in Early Access and there's still a ways to go on it but in its current state, its still quite fun (presuming you like logistics, production, and automation).  I highly recommend it!

I'm now going to quibble about small things because that's what I do when I like a game: There seems to be a lack of biodiversity in interactable flora and fauna.  The end game seems to be almost exclusively about production lines with a lot of great ideas feeling undervalued -- Factorio's bug colonies feel like an appropriate solution, albeit taken (though manning the walls and setting up flame turrets sounds super cool in a game like this).  The multiple start zones are just different spots on the same planet and the difficulty levels are misleading (personally, the "hardest" ones seem the easiest and vice-versa).  Power generation feels.. clunky -- I can produce a huge facility that should double my power production but the spikes in usage and the finickiness of the water pumps take an overly large amount of effort to smooth out.  Not a whole lot of point in exploring (which gets back to great ideas feeling underused/wasted -- like, there's some really cool vehicles).  Multiplayer continues to have glitches.

All in all, I'm excited to see what they end up doing -- hopefully updates sooner rather than later.

The creatures are fascinating, I'm thankful for the arachnophobia mode, and the game is easy to just start up and play. It also doesn't require internet! 96867310.review: After the fun i have been getting with dyson sphere program which 3rd person wider angle, i also now sucked into this other "logistics base building open world' game early access as well but i find much more my style. Mostly because it actually first person so instead of hovering above you are on the ground, the structures are above you, you have jump climb and parkour around your constructions. For early access is very clean from bugs, lots of hours of game play to do, there is early access PVE but the wildlife is no pushover. This has a very familiar ARK Survival Evolved feel to it the experience within the open world, base building, tech research is very similar but does not appear to be using the ARK engine. Even better you can co op with someone else, so work within the map build out the enviroment. I am going to be playing for sometime methinks. The game as is  already worth the $$$ i reckon and there is a lot of content within the map already coded that is not yet useful or able to engage which indicates there is a lot more to come.

96848520.review:
Satisfactory is incredibly satisfying for the OCD in me. Plenty of space for creativity and straight up ingenuity. 

However!!!
I found the wildlife to be annoying and impractical in relation to the environment. Some have ridiculously unlimited chemical like fireballs and all of them will always attack you. Few predators will attack 100% of the time. Most will always put on a show to avoid conflict for that matter. But these ones come after you fearlessly 100% of the time. All in an effort to guard minerals or crashed drones? The AI needs serious work. 

End Thought,
If you add a few smart Mods to this game, you can have hours of endless amusement. So, if you are creative and LOVE to build, but find wildlife and indestructible gas tubes to be annoying. MOD it !

96708056.review: Essentially 3D factorio with so much more. With great music and great gameplay whats not to love? It is also VERY satisfying to see your factory work. (It is in the title, Satisfactory).

96705561.review: I don't want to just compare this game to Factorio, but I feel like I have to.  In Factorio, I'm continually expanding my factory, and the way upgrades work steers me toward progressively introducing a new challenge and automating the one that I just solved.  In Satisfactory, it feels like I know what I want to do, but the game is trying to stop me from having too much fun right away.  All of the resources I need are too far away, I can't passively craft things from my inventory while walking around (like I can in Factorio), power sources are very limited early on in the game, alien enemies and health regen severely limit your ability to explore for the first several hours, and on and on.  It leads to a whole lot of waiting around for things to happen, because the game puts too many obstacles in your way in the early game for you to continually automate away that tedium.  Maybe it gets better later, or maybe the game just did an exceptionally poor job of steering me toward the right way to play the game, but the sheer act of making a factory in 3D space doesn't make up for the tedium introduced here.

96610629.review:
Coffee Stain Studios brings objects alive in a way that I just love. The machinery with all the amazing animations just blows my mind for some reason. I love how interactable all the machines feel and how much control over the whole experience you have. I figured 169.0 hours was a good place to stop and write a review for this amazing game that is still in early access. 

I have still not gotten past tier 5 because getting coal power up and running was difficult and time consuming for me. Advancing into steel and other actually complicated recipes is where I kinda got stumped with all the ratios and making sure that I'm making enough of the newest thing that I don't have to wait forever to get the to the next tier. this is where you need to start scaling up to what I find is an intimidating degree. 

If I have any negatives about the game it's that the world feels really lonely there isn't a whole lot going on in the world, and I don't mean the world looks bad it's a very pretty alien planet but its pretty much just there to look at. No pollution to worry about no terrain deformation, there is some caves to explore and things to find but it just feels lacking. None of my friends own the game so I'm kind of forced to make my own fun with the game and decide on my own what to work on next. And the big bean creature's animation are a little lacking for me, it kinda folds in on itself at its joint areas and I don't like it, it just seams off compared to all the other creatures. Of witch there are 4 enemies I have come across and 4 passive creatures that I came across. apart from the spiders and lizard doggo they are kind of boring.

There is currently 8 tiers of tech in the game and I believe it will go up to 12 by full release. What they will add to those new tiers though I'm not sure as the game seems to have everything I can think of beyond some expansion to the power like some logic so I can have fun some of the stuff that currently just serves as cosmetic's. they just added drone's, zip lines, some power improvements, lights and a hand full of other things I have yet to get to.

All in all it is a great game so far a solid 8/10 for me I cant wait to spend another 169 hours just moving up two more tiers and I cant wait to see what they will add and that they will change.

96592787.review:
Who wants a short game. Well, that's not for him.
It can make you very addictive as continuous improvement and rising inventory requirements always force you to grow, which is good in this game!
The discovery and the improvements that can be extracted from the wrecked wreckage can completely rewrite the production of all the factories so far. After 700+ (Epic version) hours of playing time, the development is capable of such a turnaround that it takes an additional 500 hours to rebuild.
And even "only" early access. What if the final improvements are included?
(Before the developers and communication down the hat. Weekly live chat with players. All developers and publishers could take examples from the Coffee Stain Team!)
Thanks to them, I haven’t completely lost faith in the dedicated developers.

Aki rövid játékra vágyik.. Nos ez nem neki való.
Nagyon függővé tud tenni, mivel a folyamatos fejlesztés és emelkedő készletszükséglet mindig növekedésre kényszerit, ami ebben a játékban jó! Köszönöm nekik, hogy nem vesztettem el teljesen hitem az elhivatott fejlesztőkben.

96558793.review:
Huge world, resources, and building some insane things. There is some combat with a few creatures but the game is focused mostly on resources and production of materials. But when you need a break from blueprints go smash some bully-beast faces or find ways to climb nearby structures to rare rewards (slugs).
There is a learning curve and you can find ways to expedite many processes to speed up production. Sometimes it takes time and a *higher view*. Always keep backup storage. It's an amazing game.

96547759.review: Really great game, especially if you enjoy building games.

96547721.review:
[b]Overall: 4/5[/b] 
Satisfactory is primarily about automation, ratios, and building, with minor elements of exploration and creative expression.

[b]Gameplay 4/5[/b] 
When committing to playing a well-done automation factory game, you first have to know what you’re getting yourself into.  These games generally involve a lot of math and ratios (although you technically can play without worrying about that much, as I initially did myself).  They are also known for being extremely time consuming and addictive; not in a “Haha oh man I played for HOURS” kind of way but more like an “Oh crap it’s 4 in the morning and I forgot to eat dinner” kind of way.
Both Satisfactory and Factorio also have a plethora of well done QoL features that generally put them a tier above most other games in any genre.

[b]Difficulty/Learning Curve 4/5[/b] 
If you are into this kind of a game, the learning curve is implemented very well and is quite gradual.  You slowly build up to a larger and larger scale, in a more multiplicative kind of way rather than an additive way.  However, due to some major difficulty jumps that are inevitable in this type of a game (I’m looking at you, crude oil processing), I can’t give it a perfect score. 
The game also feels like it deals with by-products a lot more than its counterparts, but that is easily balanced out with the AWESOME-Sink.

[b]Replayability 5/5[/b] 
Once there is enough content available for an automation game, the replay values become insane.  Satisfactory is no exception. At the time of this review, I have 250 hours played, and that’s completely vanilla and mostly singleplayer.  I could easily spend another 250+ playing modded or in a multiplayer game if I wanted to, or I could just keep scaling up the desert factory that I’ve already built.

[b]Visuals 4/5[/b] 
Satisfactory is very visually pleasing and is actually optimized quite well despite having so much for your GPU/CPU to load once your factory grows larger.  However, it has been in early access for a few years, so the graphics are oh-so-slightly dated (possibly a design choice to minimize demand on your PC).  

[b]UI 5/5[/b] 
Satisfactory has an extremely well done UI that is easy to navigate.
DO NOT SLEEP ON THE TO-DO LIST!! 
Also, don’t sleep on the “hit x” feature to open up the encyclopedia.

[b]Controls 4/5[/b] 
The control set is pretty standard and will feel familiar to most gamers.  Using “c” to crouch/slide felt weird at first, but I got used to it, and it can always be rebound.
There are some minor issues with the controls, such as the hoverpack feeling like it should have a “move in the direction of the crosshair” option.
Crouch sliding constantly to go faster, however, is a very awkward mechanic. 
No autorun WHY?? 

[b]Audio 4/5[/b] 
The audio doesn’t stand out as exceptional, but it also doesn’t really fall short. The music is fitting and is quite nice, but isn’t quite as masterful and immersive as say, Astroneer or Divinity’s music.  
The machine audio is also really cool, and they do a good job with ADA’s voice, but it’s not the kind of game that I found myself turning the audio, like I did with the aforementioned games. 
I would generally be playing the game with a show or video going on in the background, so I wasn’t as interested and invested in the audio or immersion in general.

[b]Atmosphere 4/5[/b] 
Early on, the game has an extremely well done atmosphere, and I would have probably given it a 5/5 if it stayed that way.
As you progress, you focus much more on the factory itself and feel less involved with the alien world around you.  You can always go exploring, but that is truly a minor part of the game compared to building and automation.  This brings a new kind of atmosphere: the atmosphere of the well-oiled and fine-tuned machine (or absolute spaghetti mess) that is your factory.  

[b]Storyline -2/5[/b]
Unfortunately, Satisfactory’s storyline is currently very underdeveloped, but for very good reasoning.  If you start a new game and don’t skip the intro, there is absolutely a story present, but it falls off heavily after that.  
My strong personal belief is that this is because story is an absolute bottom tier priority when it comes to automation based games.  Having a great story is a welcome addition to any game, but no one is picking up Factorio or Satisfactory and saying “Man, I REALLY loved the creative story writing in that game!”  They are almost always talking about the gameplay aspects such as the amazingly well done UI and QoL features, ratios, math, etc. 

[b]Combat/Crafting Systems 2/5, 4/5[/b]
The combat system is minimal and sub-par.  You get a weapon, you dodge enemy attacks if necessary, and you poke them to death. There is a nailgun, but I never really used it. 
Combat is a very low priority in a game like this, so in my honest opinion, it is slightly irrelevant when it comes to my overall impressions of the game. 
The crafting system on the other hand is very well done.
It can be a little tedious at times, but this is likely a gameplay design intended to discourage hand crafting and encourage automation.  
The to-do list and “press x” feature make it much easier to handle.
You cannot automate the production of buildings like you can in Factorio and Dyson Sphere Program. This is an intended gameplay design, but I’m not too sure I’m that big of a fan of it.  Either way, it was easy to adjust my playstyle to just having various materials on hand rather than carrying various buildings around with me.

[b]Multiplayer 4/5[/b]
Multiplayer is a ton of fun and implemented quite well, but even the devs have said it is still unfinished and unstable.  You will likely run into minor issues here and there, such as visual glitches (like the giant item glitch), desync issues, and items disappearing.  Overall it’s done quite well and I’ve hardly had any problems, but they do exist, so I can’t give it a 5/5.  
Be sure to adjust network quality settings to the highest possible for all players.

[b]Progression/Grindiness 4/5[/b]
The progression system in this game feels very good, excluding a few difficulty hurdles.
You advance pretty steadily and you can definitely feel that advancement as you move on.
You advance similarly to how you build up: in a more multiplicative way than an additive way.  
It does start to feel a bit “grindy” towards the end. Progression definitely slows down more and more as you get into the higher tiers, and it can get to be quite tedious and drawn out in the very late game.  This absolutely works for some people, and it worked for me up until the very end of the game, where I simply lost interest because I had essentially unlocked everything.

[b]Humor 5/5[/b]
You have to look for the humor in this type of game to find it; it isn’t right in your face, but similarly to Astroneer, it comes mostly from the hilarious possibilities allowed through the physics system.  There are all kinds of things you can do to propel yourself and ragdoll your character or even launch yourself into the atmosphere. 
There are also subtle little comedic aspects presented through ADA, some of the tooltips, and the funny writings found inside the HUB. 
Most of the machines also have funny names that represent their job.

Despite the non-perfect rating, I would not hesitate one bit to highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in math, ratios, automation, production, assembly lines, and factory style games.  Even if you aren’t a math person, like yours truly, you can easily adjust your playstyle accordingly and find plenty of joy in this game.  Maybe it will even help you discover a love or appreciation for numbers that you never knew was there.
